title: How to Use a Sump Pump to Flush a Toilet with Bathtub Water

steps.headline: Get a sump pump.
steps.description: A top discharge, 1/6 HP, dirty-water sump pump with a ⁄4 inch (1.9 cm) diameter garden hose connection is recommended. You can use a side-discharge pump, but these often need priming. Clean-water pumps, designed for use in fountains, aren't appropriate for dirty bathwater, but could be used with clean water. Less powerful pumps tend to fill toilet tank slowly, or not at all. More powerful pumps tend to splash and perhaps overflow the toilet tank. You can use a connection to other sizes of hose, provided you have a hose of that size or an adapter to the size you do have. Note that larger diameters allow for faster flow. You won't need a float switch, and you can skip getting a check valve (backflow preventer), too. Test the sump pump by plugging it in, dry. If you don't hear any sound, it's not working. Unplug immediately and look for a reset switch, then try again. Unplug once testing is complete.

steps.headline: Acquire a short length of hose.
steps.description: This will be used reach from tub to toilet tank. An expandable hose is not recommended, as the back-pressure it creates reduces the flow rate, perhaps to zero. However, with a powerful pump, it could be useful in reducing the flow rate to a manageable level. The hose should reach floor, so its weight won't pull end out of tank when filled with water. You only need the connection to the pump. You can cut the other end off. If you've got a damaged hose, feel free to reuse that for this project. A longer hose is not necessarily better. It will take longer for the water to start flowing, the flow rate will be reduced, and the hose will take up more space and weigh more; once used, it will remain full of water, requiring more effort to move into the bucket or to drain.

steps.headline: Get a large bucket to hold the dripping pump and hose when not in use.
steps.description: It should hold the volume of water from the hose, for when it drains back out the pump. Should have handle strong enough to lift bucket with sump pump, water, and hose inside.

steps.headline: Get an extension cord if you need one to reach a plug.
steps.description: A power strip with an on/off switch is helpful, too. Without an on/off switch, it will be necessary to plug and unplug the pump each time it's used.

steps.headline: Buy some wide tape to secure cords to floor to prevent tripping.
steps.description: You can also use the tape to keep the hose end in the toilet tank.

steps.headline: Check and clean your equipment.
steps.description: If the sump pump or hose has been used to pump raw sewage, you should clean it first. Use the setup for installation (below), but discharge into the toilet bowl instead of tank. Run until water comes out clean. Restart pump again to ensure water is still clear. Then you can use the standard setup.

steps.headline: Fill the tub.
steps.description: This can be done by taking a bath or shower, or it can be filled with clean water. Using a top-discharge pump, you'll only need a few inches of water, but if you've got a side-discharge pump, it'll need to be fully submerged to allow for priming. However, if the water will be shut off to the house, it's best to fill tub completely, to maximize the number of flushes before it runs dry. Also note that a full tub will create a higher flow rate than a nearly empty one, due to increased intake pressure.

steps.headline: Connect the sump pump to hose.
steps.description: Tighten the connection as tightly as you can by hand. A wrench is not needed, as slight leaks back into the tub are OK.

steps.headline: Place the sump pump in tub.
steps.description: Ideally place it far from faucet, as air bubbles may get into pump from pouring water. However, if water will be shut off to tub, then place sump pump near drain, as that's the lowest point in the tub, allowing for use of the most water before the pump runs dry.

steps.headline: Remove the toilet tank lid.
steps.description: Place it on floor so it will not fall (don't lean it up against wall).

steps.headline: Place the other end of hose in toilet tank (not bowl).
steps.description: Ideally, position it so the discharge is above the waterline. Secure it with tape over the toilet tank opening, to prevent hose from flipping out when water flows. Also wrap the tape around the hose, sticky side in, or it may slowly work it's way backwards. More is better here (better to be safe than sorry).

steps.headline: Tape the cords and hose down to floor, to prevent tripping.
steps.description: There should be no place for a toe to hook on a cord or hose.

steps.headline: Optionally, turn off normal water supply to toilet.
steps.description: You can also use both together, to fill tank more quickly.

steps.headline: Plug the sump pump into extension cord and/or power strip if needed/desired.
steps.description: Don't plug into outlet unless you have a power strip between the two, turned off. Most sump pumps lack on/off switches, so expect it to come on as soon as it has electricity.

steps.headline: Ideally two people should be present.
steps.description: One monitors discharge to catch hose if it flips out, while the other operates the power switch.

steps.headline: Turn the sump pump on.
steps.description: (Either by flipping the switch on the power strip, or by plugging it in, if you lack a switch.)

steps.headline: Check if you need to prime the pump.
steps.description: If pump is on, but water does not flow, you may need to prime the pump. This is especially a problem with side-discharge pumps. Turn the pump off, then turn it upside down, entirely underwater, to let air bubbles out. Shake vigorously, until air bubbles stop. You may need to repeat this process several times, until water flows normally. When air gets back into pump, the process needs to be repeated, so turn the water on in tub if the water level drops near the intake.

steps.headline: Fill toilet tank to fill line.
steps.description: Flush normally.

steps.headline: Refill toilet tank, then turn off pump.
Lift end of hose above waterline in toilet tank to allow air in.
steps.description: This prevents suction from causing backflow back into the tub. Leave end of hose in toilet tank for next use, or remove the sump pump and hose, according to the next steps. Do not allow hose to fall onto floor, as the water inside it will pour out, even with the sump pump off.

steps.headline: Remove the pump when you don't want it in the tub.
steps.description: When not in use, you can place the sump pump and hose in a bucket. Some dripping and backflow out of the hose is to be expected, unless equipped with a check valve. There's no need to drain and dry the pump between uses, as they are designed to sit wet.

steps.headline: Leave it be if you prefer.
steps.description: If the tub is not needed for bathing, this setup can be left in place.
